title: Question 63

children: A 64-year-old woman has been hospitalized for 4 days for a first COPD exacerbation and is now being discharged. Before hospitalization she had mild symptoms such as breathlessness when hurrying on level ground or walking up a slight hill. She stopped smoking 7 years ago. Immunizations are up to date. Medications are a fluticasone furoate-umeclidinium-vilanterol inhaler and an additional day of prednisone.

Which of the following is the most appropriate additional treatment?
Pulmonary rehabilitation has numerous benefits in patients with COPD, including reduced symptoms, improved quality of life, and decreased frequency of hospitalizations.

Addition of pulmonary rehabilitation should be considered for patients with COPD and moderate to severe symptoms and patients experiencing at least one exacerbation per year, particularly in those recently hospitalized after an exacerbation.
The most appropriate treatment is pulmonary rehabilitation (
Option C

). This patient has been hospitalized for a COPD exacerbation and is ready for discharge. The most important next step is to optimize her therapy. Pulmonary rehabilitation integrates exercise training, education, and nutritional and social support for patients with chronic lung conditions. It has numerous benefits, including reduced symptoms, improved quality of life, and decreased frequency of hospitalizations, in patients with COPD. Addition of pulmonary rehabilitation is recommended for patients with COPD and moderate to severe symptoms (e.g., having to walk more slowly than others of same age due to breathlessness, having to stop to catch breath when walking on level ground at own pace, or having more severe breathlessness) and for patients experiencing at least one COPD exacerbation per year, particularly in those recently hospitalized after an exacerbation. This patient meets the criteria for pulmonary rehabilitation.
α

) can slow the progression of emphysema in patients with α
-antitrypsin deficiency, but it is not effective for the treatment of COPD in patients without α

-antitrypsin level should be obtained once in all patients with COPD. If α
-antitrypsin deficiency is diagnosed, augmentation therapy might be indicated. It would be premature to provide augmentation therapy without first measuring the α
-antitrypsin level.

The National Emphysema Treatment Trial (NETT) demonstrated that patients with upper-lobe-predominant emphysema and significant exercise limitations even after participation in a pulmonary rehabilitation program had improved quality of life, exercise tolerance, pulmonary function, and survival with lung volume reduction surgery (
Option B
). This patient has homogenous emphysema, and there is no evidence of exercise limitations.
